_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This RMP pertains to Reeve Agri-Energy (RAE), a production facility located in Garden City, Kansas that manufactures fuel-grade denatured ethanol.  This executive summary is structured from the requirements specified in ? 68.155.  The following paragraphs A through F intend to specifically address the requirements in paragraphs (a) through (f) in ? 68.155.



A)    It is the policy of RAE to implement the requirements of the Risk Management Program (RMP) in accordance with the USEPA regulations under 40 CFR Part 68.  The objective is to prevent an explosion, fire, and/or a release of natural gasoline denaturant while also minimizing the potential impacts to RAE employees, the public, and the environment in the unlikely event of a release.  RAE plans to accomplish these objectives by utilizing good operating procedures, maintaining an appropriate preventative maintenance program for the equipment, providing proper training to RAE employees, hiring reputable qualified contractors, and coordinating emergency response activities with local emergency management services.



B)    RAE is production facility that manufactures fuel-grade denatured ethanol.  Currently denaturant storage and use is the only RMP process at RAE.  The denaturant, natural gasoline, is used to render the product ethanol unfit for human consumption.  Natural gasoline is a flammable liquid mixture containing isopentane, pentane, and butane as well as other substances.  



C)    An offsite consequence analysis for denaturant storage and use was conducted for RAE using RMP*Comp in accordance with the requirements in 40 CFR 68.  Both an unlikely Worst Case Scenario vapor cloud explosion and a more realistic Alternative Release Scenario pool fire at loadout were conducted for the denaturant process.  The key concepts of the accident prevention program at RAE include utilizing good operating procedures, maintaining an appropriate preventative maintenance program for the equipment, providing proper training to RA

E employees, hiring reputable qualified contractors, and coordinating emergency response activities with local emergency management services.  



D)    At the time of this filing, RAE has not had any applicable accidents or releases.  



E)    Emergency response at RAE is coordinated with the Garden City Fire Department so that in the event of an accident immediate response measures can be implemented.  RAE's current policy is one of limited first response.  RAE will evacuate and secure the facility while waiting for local emergency management services to provide full response.  RAE maintains written emergency action plans.  



F)    RAE will continue to evaluate and implement changes as necessary to improve safety and minimize the risk of accidental releases at RAE.
